text:
The Nigerian government has a foreign policy for Africa that often got a lot of  Nigerian citizens talking. For instance, spending a total of $64 billion in fighting apatheid while citizens suffered made no sense at all. But as we Nigerians matured in life, we got to understand 'the curse of the big brother' . All those sacrifices over the years has earned Nigeria the status of "the giant of Africa" and the world has taken note believing and coming to invest in Nigeria in droves despite the insecurity in the country. Generosity is not foolishness, but it's a form of investment because being selfless always has its pay backs one way or the other. Nigerians are known to be very generous people. But Xenophobia to me shows weakness and lack of confidence because it reveals a lack of willingness to compete. As a Nigerian, I don't have any business in SA and never will. Gone are the days when SA used to be an attractive destination for Nigerians, now its other Africans that see SA as a worthy destination.
So yeah, the purpose of the Xen attacks is yealding fruit for South Africans as Nigerians are looking inwards now. With world class infrastructure springing up everywhere, Nigeria has quickly become the number one destination for tech and entertainment in Africa. Everyone is coming to Nigeria. Xenophobia can continue even as a state policy in SA for all I care, the future looks brighter for Nigeria as an emerging giant amongst nations of the world. Wish u guys luck

text:
Why don't we also look at what poor South Africans who live in Townships suffer due to illegal immigrants.  The are over hundred of cases like the ones bellow:

1.      A Pakistani national and 29 other people arrested after a raid at the Department of Home Affairs' offices in Krugersdorp face various charges. The suspects, aged between 19 and 42, are expected to appear in court on Monday. They face charges of fraud, corruption, contravention of the Immigration Act, and the possession of suspected fraudulent documents.

2.      Johannesburg - Police have arrested 42 people following xenophobic attacks in Rosettenville, Gauteng‚Äôs police commissioner said on Thursday.  One was arrested for possession of an unlicensed firearm, 14 were nabbed for possession of or dealing in drugs, and 27 were foreigners without proper documentation, Lieutenant Gen General Deliwe de Lange said in a statement.

3.      Peter Akadoronge, 37, was convicted on three counts of human trafficking, two counts of rapes of adults that happened more than once and one count of assault with intent to inflict grievous bodily harm, following an incident that happened in Thohoyandou on November 26, 2017.  The court heard three women went in search of employment when they were approached by three Nigerian men who offered them employment.
